reviewText: I enjoy watching shows that display good writing, and good acting.  This one has so much of that.  The plots are intelligent, and often portray what our current society actually lives, without being an outright "soap opera."  Some of the characters are a bit extreme in their portrayal of some political figures, but even that illustrates what is often wrong with our political scene currently.I especially enjoy the characters of Alicia Florrick and Cary Agos.  I find Will Gardner often obnoxious, but the writers may have intended  that.  I feel Alicia is far too good a person to waste herself on either Peter Florrick or Will Gardner.One of the most interesting characters is Kalinda Sharma.  I love to watch Archie Punjabi in her role.  She is so attractive physically while portraying a personality that seemingly has no moral standards about sexual behaviour.  Seems that Kalinda smoothly uses most everyone she needs in order to do her job. Fascinating personality, but probably desperately lonely. Makes one wonder what molded this person's outlook on life.The legal aspect of this story is interesting, while often blurred about what is realistic.  Even so, it is one of my favorites.

reviewText: Stone-faced Alicia Florrick has an on-going physical and emotional affair with her homely looking Law Firm Boss/Sr. Partner/Ex-College Sweetheart, after her good looking state's attorney for Cook County husband was imprisoned after a sex and corruption scandal, of which he is later found innocent. Alicia deals with the public humiliation by focusing on her newly ignited law career and her on-going affair with her homely Law Firm Boss/Sr. Partner/Ex-College Sweetheart, who she openly admits she doesn't love, while she definitely still loves her husband.  The hypocrisy of "appearing" to hold moral high, ground while cheating just as her husband did, even after he has apologized, renewed his faithfulness, and cleaned up his public office sure does not make her "The Good Wife" just because she isn't divorcing her husband. On top of that Alicia is an avowed atheist, while her daughter and estranged husband seek and find Christianity, while her children fend off the sexual advances of multiple admirers.  The show does good job of revealing the unnecessary dramatic cesspool any person would find themselves in if they were so morally conflicted to knowingly choose to do the wrong thing on a recurrent basis.  Alan Cumming, Chris Noth, Zach Grenier, Archie Panjabi, and Graham Phillips are dead-on true to their characters and nail every scene they are in. Julianna Margulies, who I really would like to like more, is as animated as a Mannequin, while  "Matt" Czuchry, Christine Baranski,  Makenzie Vega, and  "Josh" Charles are mis-cast for their roles. It's an interesting Chicago version of "Dynasty" or "Dallas", with VERY creative writing.
summary: Good, But Not So Good Wife!

reviewText: TGW strikes me as great entertainment.  First of all I love the real-life political parody of seeing people whom I will never meet like Rahm Emanuel, Bill Clinton, John Edwards, Mark Zuckerberg, and so forth come before my screen in parody and homage.  The show draws on politicians and celebrities and their troubled lives and weaves plots out of those threads.  Secondly, the characters are appealing - brilliant and well-dressed Diana, lovely, sincere and thoughtful Juliana, the teenagers - good kids in turmoil, Will, sharp as a legal eagle, the horrifying mothers-in-law, and so forth.  And these people to varying degrees are either lovely to look at or terrifying to behold.  Judges are a constant source of amusement, and the show may be kinder to them than their real life inspirations deserve. Or maybe not. The sphere of the intellect and the sphere of soap (emotionality) are blended in this pure escape.  Watch it from the beginning, episode by episode, season by season.  The production values are high, theatric, and the ensemble thrilling. Hats off and kudos.

reviewText: I love THE GOOD WIFE.  Season One is one of the best seasons of television, period.  And the best thing about this show has always been the relationship between Alicia Florrick (Julianna Margulies) and Kalinda Sharma (Archie Panjabi).  Unfortunately, two decisions made by the writers have irreparably damaged this relationship, and consequently the series.  First, at the end of Season Two the writers decided to reveal that Kalinda slept with Alicia's husband during her stint at the State's Attorney's office two years before the show began.  This undermined the friendship that had grown between these two very different women.  And second, in Season Four, they brought in new character Nick (Marc Warren), Kalinda's long-lost abusive husband.  This guy shows up in the first episode of Season Four as a thug with a criminal record attempting to use Lockhart Gardner to help him get a towing contract from the State.  But his real motive is to move in on Kalinda again and get his hands on some money he believes she stole from him.The problem here is that Kalinda has always been portrayed as a strong and self-sufficient woman.  Yes, she was "mysterious," and it was obvious from the start that she had secrets she was hiding, but it seems totally against character to portray her locked in a love-hate battle with an abusive lunatic.  While things are left a bit murky as to what Kalinda's relationship with Nick really is, they are shown punching each other, going full-on martial arts with each other, pulling guns on each other, and having what can only be called sadomasochistic sex with each other.  In fact, their first "sex scene" looks very much like rape, although it is left up in the air as to whether or not Kalinda was into the whole rape scenario.This storyline permeates the first half of Season Four, and the first ten episodes are undeniably marred by its presence.  By mid-season, however, the writers seemed to get it (fans were not happy), and Nick was abruptly written out (although his story was left open-ended).I didn't really begin enjoying Season Four until episode 11 ("Boom De Yah Da"), which is the first without Nick's appearance.  There's also a great scene in that episode between Alicia and Kalinda that recalls their relationship in the first two seasons.  Julianna Margulies has said that she herself could never forgive a friend who had done what Kalinda did (sleeping with Peter), and I think the writers have been influenced by her feelings about the storyline.  That's unfortunate, since I've missed the Alicia/Kalinda friendship and hope to see it get back on track in Season Five.There are some good characters in Season Four, including the return of Louis Canning (Michael J. Fox), Elsbeth Tascioni (Carrie Preston), and Mike Kresteva (Mathew Perry).  Notable new additions include Clarke Hayden (Nathan Lane), a trustee appointed to help Lockhart Gardner avoid bankruptcy, and Maddie Haywood (Maura Tierney), a wealthy woman who befriends Alicia and then becomes competition for Peter.  THE GOOD WIFE has always been adept at using guest stars to great advantage, and Season Four is no exception.Overall, if you're a fan of the series (and I most definitely am), you won't want to miss Season Four.  There's plenty of drama as Lockhart Gardner tries to survive an impending financial crisis, and Peter's run for the governorship is equally compelling. Just be aware of the weak first half.  I'm also disappointed in the writers' decision to continue with the on-again-off-again Alicia/Will romance.  While believable, a romantic relationship between these two characters makes Alicia seem weaker, and more vulnerable to the same kinds of things she dealt with in her marriage to Peter.  That said, the conflict in Alicia's mind between her very understandable sexual attraction to Will and her commitment to her husband and children is compelling.  The final moments of Season Four set up a scenario for Season Five that may or may not mean she has finally chosen one path over the other - but the writers leave it brilliantly inscrutable.  Will Alicia jump back into a passionate liaison with Will, or will she recommit to Peter and her family?  It's a delicious dilemma, and I, for one, can't wait!First half of Season Four:  2 starsSecond half of Season Four:  4 starsOverall:  3 stars
summary: Weak first half mars otherwise strong season

reviewText: I thought, hoped she and we were home safe, that she was tempted but was still going to be the Good Wife. I want her to be the hero-mother who knows how much her being unfaithful can hurt her children. So even though tempted, she withstands. Some things, like your children, are worth the sacrifice. But the writers can't do it that way. They think that they have to hold the viewers by letting her lose to those all important feelings that we must obey...feelings excuse us from all responsibility. Come on, writers, give us meat: tenderloin, not pig slop, not watered down half truths about successful ways to live life. We know what doesn't work. That's what we watch on TV. Now we want to see someone do life the right way. Will and Good Wife are aware of the consequences of their actions. They work together and are attracted to each other. So? Show us their other possibilities- not that they give in to their sexual attraction-but they find another solution/s. Maybe they do what we ask our children to do. They just say No! and get on with life. Surely the writers can be creative in a way that excludes the bedroom, drugs, tasteless language. Using interesting characters-develop them further. Using interesting law cases combined with funny characters-take them a step further. The writers have been so good so far, have done so many things right. But when they go towards the bedroom, whether it be with Will and Alicia or Kalinda and Husband, etc., it feels unnatural, like they're off topic. Write the stuff you're good at, not trash.

reviewText: I became hooked on this show when I signed up for Amazon Prime and binged on the first three seasons. I waited impatiently for the fourth season to become available. Finally, $0.00! But I'm halfway through the series and it's such a letdown. The plot lines have strayed to relationships, while the bread-and-butter stories -- legal and courtroom battles -- are pushed to the side. I'm tired of skipping though the stuff I don't like (and even find repulsive).Here are the Top Ten things I dislike about the fourth season. If most of them don't change, I'm outta here.1. Nick has to go! He's skeevy, ugly and dragging the whole show down.2. Put Kalinda back to work. Hang up her baseball bat and black belt and keep her out of the bedroom.3. There's not enough of Eli! Give us more... but not of his personal life. Keep him on the campaign trail.4. Forget the Will-and-Alicia romance. There's no chemistry there.5. More Will-and-Diane! Their working relationship, I mean. But please don't put them in the bedroom. (Ditch all the bedroom scenes while you're at it. No one needs to go there.) More Cary at work, too.6. Give us more parenting savvy. Zach and Grace are great kids facing universal teen issues. Show us how Alicia and Peter help them through.7. Spare us Alicia's mom! Veronica is ridiculous. (And give her brother, Owen, something to do other than mope.)8. Spare us Peter's mom! Except the scenes with her nurse companion. He's a hoot! But don't make it into a May-December romance.9. Give us more of the political back-biting of Peter's campaign. It's delicious!10. More courtroom and legal drama, please. But keep the violence and graphic images off-stage, as they were at first. Oh, and bring the firm out of bankruptcy, and put us all out of our misery.Thank you in advance, and I hope to see you next season!
summary: My "Top Ten" for fixing The Good Wife

reviewText: We are currently watching two episodes per night of this show.  (So that tells you something!)  The writing is great, as is the acting.  The characters are so richly nuanced, that you forget they're not real people.  Alan Cumming, as Eli Gold, is spot-on as a high-powered "crisis manager" and campaign Svengali, who also has a very fragile side he tries hard to hide. His facial expressions alone are plenty of reason to watch the show.  Chris Noth as Peter Florrick is so believable as a flawed politician and a man who is struggling to win back his wife, Alicia (Julianna Margulies) after a very public scandal.  I have already sung the praises of the female members of the cast in a review of the third season.  I am amazed that they've been able to keep the quality of this show at such a high level year after year.Sometimes I have to stretch credulity a little bit to believe that Alicia (the main character) would put up with some of the abuse she suffers at work.  But haven't we all had to put up with some kind of unpleasantness at the workplace?  And the law, as a profession, does not come out smelling like a rose! But I guess that's more realistic than I would like to think.All in all, great show.

reviewText: Thanks to Amazon, I became a Good Wife fan a few months ago and binge-watched the first 3 seasons.  The actors are appealing and the script is frequently delicious, especially when Peter runs for office or has to do a deal with a devil (Wendy Scott-Carr?) in order to buy credibility.  The relationship between Alicia and Peter seems real and complex and just as fraught as you might expect.  As a lawyer, the legal bits of this show are almost unwatchable.  From the very first season it was ridiculous, but it gets ever more so as time goes on and in this 4th season it's downright laughable.  It's like a pointillist version of the law -- if you stay very far away it looks plausible, but as you get closer it looks more and more like nothing.  The basics of the cases are interesting, but the timeframes and behavior of lawyers are just insane and unrealistic.  Kalinda the magical "law firm investigator" does not have a job found at most law firms and since she transgresses the law regularly, LG would constantly be in trouble.  Honestly, no big firm is doing that much criminal work, and especially it's not doing blood and guts criminal work. Still, I watch because although the courtroom drama is terrible, the relationships between and among people do feel real.  Law firms do have partners like David Lee, and Diane, and (to a lesser extent) Will and they react in more or less real ways. The personalities of the various judges feel right also. All in all, it's an entertaining show.
summary: Legally improbable, romantically improbable, still fun

reviewText: I've watched the Good Wife  on my Kindle Fire (with prime you get the first four seasons free!).  The title of this show is a bit misleading because it's about a family split apart by a philandering husband who is now in a high position in government and running for governor while trying to keep the facade of his marriage as if all was well though the public is well aware he has had several 'sessions' with prostitutes. The wife is slowly letting him back in her good graces but first has an affair of her own which her husband suspects. The show really spends more time in the courtroom and the offices where the wife has, after 15 years away, restarted her career. The husband played by Chris Noth (of Sex and the City) and Julianna Marquiles (of ER fame) plays his wife but we see more of her as a competent and extremely talented lawyer who could seemingly do well on her own. I have to say I like the Good Wife more than Scandal. The twists and turns the show is taking are just as show-stopping as in Scandal and for no particular reason or reasons I can't express this show has become one of my favorites.Alan Cummings, Stockard Chaning, Christine Baranski (Cybil) are the most well known of the cast  do a damn good job. Nathan Lane gives a amazing performance as well as many other guest stars you would recognize from other shows.If you have not seen The Good Wife do give it a gander....If you are a prime member check out the first four seasons on your tablet or Fire or any Amazon product that will stream to see if you love it and you can go from there. I had a marathon and I hated when the battery ran down so when it was charged I was right back.I can't forget the unbelievably good performance(s) by Michael J. Fox. He plays an opposing lawyer and is magnificent in several of the shows.The Good Wife--A winner and  fantastically good show.Check it out!!!

reviewText: This series is one of the best, most intelligent and thoroughly entertaining series on television.  It centers on Alicia Florrick, a lawyer working her way in a top law firm after being out of the workforce for many years.  She's married to Peter Florrick, a man driven by political ambition, who was caught with his pants down literally, after having had extra-marital affairs, including frequenting prostitutes.  He's in the process of resurrecting his tarnished reputation and realizing his desire to be Governor.  Alicia does an incredible balancing act between moving up in her own career, with all of its pitfalls and victories, while being the wronged wife who stands by her man in an attempt to salvage her badly damaged marriage.  She is, however, her own woman, bright, intuitive and total class.  I love this series.  Can hardly wait for the new season to begin!
